title: Monday, 9th April, 2018
bodyHTML:
Blank canvas good morning everyone
11:06 am
BE11:06am

Hello. Good morning, hi, hey there, welcome to Monday.

Soundbuy Morning
VV75 morning
dfd Hello
BE11:07am

Start here, I guess.

BE11:07am

SoS Good Morning
Paper Chase Hullo
11:08 am
BE11:08am

Not an unqualified success for Deripaska’s sort-of-London-listed thing.

Grouchmonkey Morning
Soundbuy Sanctions??
BE11:09am

Could be worse. Rusal (majority owned by EN+, HK listed with various GDRs and stuff on Euronext and so on) down about 50%.

Grouchmonkey Ouchy
BE11:10am

And, yeah, it's sanctions.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

https://home.treas...ies-in-response-to

BE11:11am

Sanctions quite specifically against oligarchs ... which is an approach, I guess.

BE11:11am

Oleg Deripaska is being designated pursuant to E.O. 13661 for having acted or purported to act for or on behalf of, directly or indirectly, a senior official of the Government of the Russian Federation, as well as pursuant to E.O. 13662 for operating in the energy sector of the Russian Federation economy. Deripaska has said that he does not separate himself from the Russian state. He has also acknowledged possessing a Russian diplomatic passport, and claims to have represented the Russian government in other countries. Deripaska has been investigated for money laundering, and has been accused of threatening the lives of business rivals, illegally wiretapping a government official, and taking part in extortion and racketeering. There are also allegations that Deripaska bribed a government official, ordered the murder of a businessman, and had links to a Russian organized crime group.

VV75 Evraz going down in sympathy/fear
11:11 am
BE11:12am

I think I can quote that? I mean, it's an official treasury.gov statement.

BE11:13am

The link to which is above. Though we wish to make it clear that the views and positions of the US government are not necessarily those of this website.

LJ fairly serious 'allegations' made, surely there will be further investigations post the sanctioning?
J L Morning
BE11:14am

This is excellent from Max and Courtney, trying to pick out sense from the move: https://www.ft.com...-b7e0-52972418fec4

Miss Piggy @BE: because you don't wear the legal risk u.s. department of the treasury
11:14 am
BE11:14am

In terms of impact ......

BE11:15am

Note the line reported earlier that the US will also attempt to restrict non-US citizens from "knowingly facilitating significant transactions... for or on behalf of them."

BE11:17am

Which, if effective, seems to have an unknown ripple effect across the market.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Particularly as metals are priced in $

BE11:17am

Here's BMO

BE11:18am

The impact on the power segment will likely be minimal given its sales are almost entirely within Russia. However, RUSAL may find it more difficult to do business given that it is the second-largest supplier of aluminium to the U.S. after Canada (~10% of RUSAL's output). Furthermore, given the attempt to limit even non-U.S. citizens from facilitating transactions it is possible that activities as simple as exchanging currencies may become more expensive for RUSAL given the international scope of its operations and sales being priced in U.S. dollars. Separately, this action by the U.S. Government may push aluminium premiums up even further in the wake of the trade tariffs that were recently enacted.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

There is also the risk that forced sellers emerge in the equities. The list of U.S. registered shareholders in En+ is small, although it is possible that the owners of shares registered in other jurisdictions may also be compelled to sell. However, U.S. registered holdings in RUSAL are more meaningful, and any downward pressure on RUSAL's share price could flow through to En+. As well as the risk of forced sellers, it is also difficult to asses where marginal buyers might step in.

BE11:19am

They were buyers of EN+ and now they're not.

Mouselet Good morning assorted capitalists
Grouchmonkey Who owns Alcan canada these days? Rio bought it, but didn't they then spin it off?
Otter Hello Friendos
Peace and Love Bonjour les amis
BE11:21am

In terms of the readthrough for stuff that isn't GDRs ....

11:20 am
EVRAZ plc (EVR:LSE): Last: 382.90, down 67.6 (-15.01%), High: 450.00, Low: 372.50, Volume: 4.22m
Polymetal International PLC (POLY:LSE): Last: 640.60, down 83.4 (-11.52%), High: 727.60, Low: 630.60, Volume: 632.48k
Blank canvas any views on Deutsche Bank and its reshuffle?
Grouchmonkey Don't worry I've caught up. thankyou Wikipedia.
Mouselet But KAZ is OK?
Mouselet I am never entirely sure about the status of oligarchs in ex-Soviet countries.
RuminationsOn If the US believes that sanctions against Oligarchs and the favoured kleptocracy will impact Kremlin thinking I am afraid that their Russian intelligence gathering has been delivering wishful thinking.Telling the Kremlin (sic) that you are hurting financially because of sanctions is a sub-optimal strategy.
BE11:23am

"Further escalation is the baseline" is the gist of the comment I'm getting through this morning.

11:24 am
BE11:25am

Anyway, we have aluminium up very sharply and miners down quite a lot ....

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 339.90, down 11.25 (-3.20%), High: 347.30, Low: 339.70, Volume: 30.32m
Fresnillo PLC (FRES:LSE): Last: 1,217, down 25 (-2.01%), High: 1,262, Low: 1,216, Volume: 177.54k
11:25 am
Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 1,586, down 32.4 (-2.00%), High: 1,624, Low: 1,583, Volume: 1.41m
Antofagasta PLC (ANTO:LSE): Last: 902.00, down 13.6 (-1.49%), High: 923.20, Low: 900.40, Volume: 258.90k
Kaz Minerals PLC (KAZ:LSE): Last: 852.00, down 14.8 (-1.71%), High: 878.20, Low: 850.40, Volume: 449.25k
11:26 am
BE11:26am

Oh, should mention that SocGen has a downgrade of Anglo out today, unrelated to anything we've just typed but worth mentioning nonetheless.

nichoman why's polymetal hit so hard ?
BE11:27am

We are still constructive on the long-term sector outlook and raise some of our commodity price assumptions, notably for copper and coal. However, we see limited near-term upside in the commodity complex after a two-year rally and now expect momentum in equities to slow. Seeking shelter in value and rerating potential, we move from Hold to Buy on BHP (TP £14.04=-£16.00), stick to Glencore as our top pick, and downgrade Anglo American from Buy to Hold on price performance.

BE11:28am

China entered 2018 on a high note, but SG’s economist think this strong start could prove to be a high-water mark with momentum slowing ahead. [...] We reiterate our positive long-term stance on the base metal complex but see limited near-term upside as favourable conditions appear to be largely discounted by the market. We think bulk commodities have peaked, with prices
likely to stay under pressure in the near term as China in particular cools. That said, given positive demand momentum in emerging markets, we are now more constructive on coal as opposed to iron ore in view of low inventories and constrained supply.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Metals & Mining has materially outperformed the commodity complex over the
last two years, a rare divergence. As such, M&M stocks could face headwinds as the
commodities rally starts to cool. We therefore shift our emphasis to relative value and
rerating potential.

Mouselet interesting question, since neither it nor any of its owners are mentioned in the sanctions document
BE11:29am

We reiterate Glencore as our top pick (Buy, £4.70=-£4.20), with
the lower TP reflecting GBP appreciation and an extra discount to account for DRC risks.
We downgrade Anglo American to Hold (£16.50=-£17.50) on share price growth, with the
stock being one of the best performers in the sector. We upgrade BHP Billiton to Buy
(£14.04=-£16.00) on stronger profit outlook and dividend potential. We prefer BHP
(19.5% TSR) to Anglo (13.6%) and Rio (Buy, £44.00=-£40.50, 16.7% TSR). We also
upgrade the TP of Vale ($4.86=-$13.50), reflecting the progress in deleveraging, strong
FCF and organic growth potential, but leave the Hold rating unchanged given the share
price gains.

BE11:29am

92 pages, of which that's the first.

11:29 am
undefined
FATDAZ says a lot about the diminished weighting of the miners that FTSE is still clinging to positive territory on the day no ?
Grouchmonkey Rio's up though
FATDAZ @ grouch good point
Soundbuy 92 pages - that kept the intern busy........
BE11:31am

On Polymetal ............

Upaswellasdown Morning all. There is no news hook for this question but does anyone have any informed views on ConvaTec?
urgeview could go up as well as down ?
BE11:33am

..... there's the obvious, which is the expectation/risk of further sanctions and an escalation that sees the US just move down Wikipedia's "oligarch" list.

Tom Dalgleish Is it better to have a Sir as Chairman or not?
11:33 am
BE11:33am

Gold miners also a bit weak across the board .....

BE11:34am

... but we've also got JPM Caz negative, which probably has an effect at the margin.

Tom Dalgleish My experience of political feather dusters is they are next to useless as Chair
BE11:34am

[W]e identify a growing probability that the company will approve a new $650m capital investment programme in 2018/19, which will delay de-leveraging that may lead to reduced financial flexibility and lower shareholder
returns. Polymetal’s operating costs and valuation face potential headwinds if the RUB/$ continues to strengthen. Polymetal’s 2018E EV/EBITDA is trading in line with its 6 year average of 7.0x.

11:34 am
BE11:35am

Our Underweight recommendation reflects our view that Polymetal’s equity multiple
and valuation carry downside risk due to rising costs inflation in Russia, plus a likely
significant delay in FCF generation if a new $650m capex programme is approved.
Our indicative analysis on a new Pressure Oxidation Plant expansion suggests
underwhelming returns.

BE11:35am

Doesn't Poly have results soon? Or at least an update due? 18th April, I think?

Upaswellasdown @ urgeview. That is good to know. Most of my investments seem incapable of doing that.
sprout Bloomberg going belt and braces on EN+ and Rusal sanctions: they've even deleted the historic data and replaced with a holding page.
undefined
nichoman thanks - well I guess renewed sanctions should at least should stop the RUB strengthening for a while
11:36 am
BE11:36am

(@sprout: seriously!?)

sprout @BE yep
Miss Piggy link?
Miss Piggy or its this a terminal page?
Grouchmonkey @sprout interesting - expecting a suspension maybe?
sprout terminal page
sprout GDRs are suspended
BE11:37am

.......... Now that that's done to death, what else can we cover?

sprout Citi pulled the GDR programme for EN+
Otter Mr. Sprout is right.
Philruffin anything new on shire?
BE11:39am

On the En+ thing, is this because of .......

11:39 am
BE11:39am

The Company was informed by late evening on Friday, 6 April 2018, that Citi Depositary Receipt Services closed the books of the En+ Group plc 144A (CUSIP 29355E109) and Reg S (CUSIP 29355E208) sponsored GDR programs with immediate effect. The Company is currently analyzing the situation with its legal advisors.

BE11:39am

?

RA 'analysts' are the worst
sprout yes, think so. FCA suspended trading at 10am
BE11:40am

Or separate. I mean, layers do tend to get panicky, but pulling all data seems a bit extreme. Assuming that's what has happened.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Anyway ................

RA lets not forget last years study which found you'd be more profitable if you went against 'analysts' projections
nichoman anything on Pantheon ? Aim oiler that did very very well on back of a couple of test wells but having a disastrous day today as struck water instead of oil
jaws anything in KWS ?
BE11:40am

@Philruffin asks about Shire ......

BE11:41am

Interesting Novartis deal on the tape since we were last on air -- $8.7bn for AveXis, gene therapy thing.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

No direct readthrough for Shire, except to emphasise the possible value in the pipeline bit (which means ignoring the haemo bit).

VV75 @nicho the ceo will do interview at noon
jotec90 BNP out today saying that Pfizer and Roche could afford to buy them. Novartis potentially out after CEO saying will keep assessing bolt-on deal possibilities
BE11:43am

Note also statement late Friday from Takeda saying their analyst meeting last week said nothing that wasn't already in the bid statement.

BE11:44am

Which is true, and is something we pointed out at the time, but does rather leave an impression that Takeda's in a bit of a flap here.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Anyway, here's Exane to go through the list of counterbidders.

BE11:45am

Whilst we see reasonable portfolio overlap for all potential suitors in this report, we believe Shire
would show a particularly strong fit with Takeda, Pfizer or Roche.

BE11:45am

We calculate these three companies could achieve an all cash acquisition of Shire at our fair value
(GBP47.00) and still maintain net debt/EBITDA greater than 3x. Takeda would struggle most with affordability.

FATDAZ BTW all a very interesting note out from Blonde Monay today on the hidden risks inherent in ETFs quite an eyeopener I must say and well worth seeking out .
11:45 am
BE11:46am

That's three from Takeda, AbbVie, Allergan, Celgene, J&J, Novartis, Pfizer and Roche

BE11:47am

The upshot is that Takeda's pretty stretched .....

BE11:47am

Assuming a maximum 4x debt/EBITDA
ratio, we calculate Takeda could raise an incremental ca $38bn of debt. This is ca 40%
below Shire’s current EV. Closing that gap with equity would require at least a 60%
increase in the current share base. This would seem too aggressive. We would
therefore conclude that if Takeda aims to pursue Shire, leverage ratio must be pushed
greater than 4x to allow for a smaller equity raise, asset disposals may have to be considered and
the premium Takeda could afford to pay for Shire cannot be large.

soldsoldsupersold anything on shire?
11:48 am
BE11:48am

But for Pfizer, it's a walk .....

BE11:48am

, we believe Pfizer could pursue a debt-funded
acquisition of Shire with minimal issues. An acquisition of Shire at our fair value would
leave Pfizer with a debt ratio of just 2.6x, far lower than many other suitors we consider
in this report.

BE11:48am

(@soldsoldsupersold: no, nothing sorry.)

Soundbuy @soldsoldsupersold - cast your eyes over to the other side.........
11:49 am
BE11:49am

And that's before Consumer Healthcare's sold, which it still might be though it's looking tricky ....

BE11:49am

And Roche, same story ............

BE11:49am

Like Pfizer and J&J, Roche carries a low level of net debt to EBITDA today. We
believe an all cash acquisition of Shire at our fair value could still allow Roche to retain
a leverage ratio greater than 3x.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Exane's a £47 target on Shire, says they're at a 35% discount to sector based on 2019. "NPV analysis demonstrates that the current share price implies zero value for the entire HAE franchise and Xiidra."

BE11:51am

That kind of thing.

undefined
soldsoldsupersold my bad, excuse me
11:52 am

Grouchmonkey @fatdaz got a link?

Oh! Deutsche. Forgot Deutsche.

Miss Piggy Any Euro impact of Orban re-election?
FATDAZ @grouch here is a link to the website get in touch ask nicely and you can say I sent you http://blondemoney.co.uk/

John Cryan's been booted, Christian Sewing comes in.

BE11:54am

https://www.ft.com...-b7e0-52972418fec4

nichoman @FATDAZ haven't read it but have to say warnings on ETFs sounding very tired...had a few very complex products blow up but the vast majority of ETF world been through some pretty rocky patches just fine
11:55 am
BE11:55am

Subhead on that story says "to avert leadership crisis", though I'm not sure punting your CEO after he falls out with the Chairman really counts as "averting" .....

FATDAZ @nichoman this piece lifts the lid on creation deletion process and lack of clarity there in nd draws some interesting parallels with whats gone before ..... Though not mentioned in the text I had flashbacks to LTCM when i read it .....
BornCynic Thanks BE - what's PM up to these days now that he is not doing this?
PeterC Pantheon Resources PANR - the CEO Jay Cheatham?... brazen..
DJ any idea why AO World rallied so hard into the close on Friday?
BE11:57am

Gist from the sellside is, "hooray-ish" .....

BE11:58am

Quick line from Merrill .....

11:57 am
BE11:58am

Certainty on the CEO should provide relief to a share trading at 0.4x TNAV. Strategy changes are possible, even likely, but remain uncertain. DBK has no easy options left. Smaller CIB seems likely.

FATDAZ @DJ sounds like a squeeze to me though no special insight my end
BE11:58am

Longer line from Citi

BE11:58am

We welcome the simplification of the management structure,
which was overly complex in our view, but we struggle to see how replacing Mr
Cryan with Mr Sewing will result in a change of fortune for the bank. He is a long-
term veteran of the bank, who has not worked at any of Deutsche’s competitors and
lacks hands-on execution experience of the bank’s single biggest division – the
investment bank. Compared to some of the external candidates proposed in the
press over the past week, his appointment could be viewed as underwhelming.

11:58 am
BE11:59am

Mr Sewing’s appointment will inevitably lead to
discussions on whether Deutsche Bank will further downsize the Investment Bank
and re-focus on Private & Commercial Banking, based upon his background and
expertise. However this may be wide of the mark. Bloomberg (5 April) reported that
outgoing CEO Cryan had embarked on a review of the investment bank, with a view
to potentially scaling back in the US, whereas Chairman Achleitner still viewed the
US as critical to the global investment bank model. Interestingly we note that the
long-run average RoAs and RoEs (since 1970) of Commerzbank and Deutsche
Bank are very similar, at c0.2-0.3% and c6-7%, despite the different business mix.

BE11:59am

Citi don't like Deutsche. Too European, too institutional rather than corporate, too bespoke FICC over equities .......

BE12:00pm

... too buried in cutting costs from Postbank, too hobbled by historic underinvestment and not out of the woods for future rights issues.

12:00 pm
undefined
VV75 China comments on US tariffs just in
nichoman @DJ AO is a funny one - seen a few big moves for no reason over past few months
BE12:01pm

@Soundbuy: Murph was ill for a couple of weeks, was back for a day, and is now on holiday for another couple of weeks. He will be back, in theory.

Miss Piggy best wishes to Murph
BE12:02pm

@ROTR: didn't AO have a trading update on Friday?

Soundbuy Thanks, though I think you're answering BornCynic........
BornCynic Does not worry me................
Puntino Murph becoming like Jeffrey Bernard?
12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

(@Soundbuy, @BornCynic; apologies to both, I'm very tired and can't see straight.)

Soundbuy Head of FT Investigations or whatever taking its toll on PM.....
BE12:04pm

Right -- okay, let's knock off.

BornCynic BE - no need to apologise, call it a day and have lunch :)
Paper Chase Thanks all
Miss Piggy Best wishes to Bryce too. Cheers bye.
Soundbuy Cheers and ta..............
BE12:04pm

Thanks for the comments. Have the best Monday it's possible to have, and we'll see you back here tomorrow.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Afternoon all.
